title: Wednesday, 27th February 2019
bodyHTML:
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Hi, hello, give me a moment ....

Blank canvas good morning all
Soundbuy Morning all
Grouchmonkey Bonjour
BE11:10am

Just filing 1000 words for elsewhere in which I barely mention a 100th of the news happening this morning.

BE11:10am

Bloody hell, eh?

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Rights issues from M&S and Metro ......

Soundbuy Like buses.............
BE11:12am

Beiersdorf profit warning. Ted Baker profit warning .....

#REF! Good morning. Metro entertains me
red m&s finally gets to cut its divi in a manner thats acceptable...
BE11:12am

The Dutch piling into Air France-KLM just to have a dust up ....

Grouchmonkey @BE quite right yesterday about Ocado deal needed funding for M&S. Thank you!
11:13 am
BE11:13am

ITV crappy numbers, Playtech's long-awaited GVC deal ....

red naughty from ted baker. early jan everything ok even positive. a month later not so good. cynic would say not so good in jan, just hoping for best...
BE11:14am

And god only knows what's happening below the 350 level. We'll attempt to cover all those over the next hour, plus maybe more but probably less.

undefined
11:14 am
BE11:15am

Get the obvious one out of the way first.

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 274.90, down 28.3 (-9.33%), High: 285.00, Low: 272.40, Volume: 9.40m
FATDAZ @BE can understand the MKS rights issue as you predicted but stumped by metrobank having read elsewhere that debt is cheaper than equity for financials
BE11:15am

Cash call, as expected by everyone except those who were buying the shares yesterday ....

VV75 good call yesterday by you Bryce
11:16 am
BE11:16am

.... to fully fund a hugely expensive deal to capture a ~1 per cent share of the massively competitive and nearly margin-free UK groceries market.

BE11:17am

Oh, and they've chucked in a dividend cut as well.

BE11:17am

Why? Because they can, it appears.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The Ocado deal gives sufficient cover to avoid awkward headlines re the divi. It's not required, it's just convenient.

chad_john I hold MKS. I may not do by the end of the day. Beyond annoyed about the divi cut.
BE11:18am

The follow-up question that needs kicked around is, "what on earth is M&S doing?"

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Good morning all.
red trying to get a higher pe
VV75 running after the pack, in total panic
nightingale20201 morning all
wayneJ I reckon for £900M M&S could offer every mum a free coffee after the school run - that would do more for sales and profitability than OCDO
chad_john I think the Ocado thing is a good strategic move personally.
chad_john I don't think its the blind panic buy everyone is assuming it to be
wayneJ Surely the play now is WMT merging Asda with M&S?
wayneJ And then a counter bid from SBRY? Or Waitrose?
BE11:20am

It's looked at a crowded, structurally unprofitable market where the economics don't really make sense on the small basket size that's been the cornerstone of its Food division and thought, "sure, whatever, have some money."

FATDAZ @wayne j good point :)
chad_john @BE - but the point is, they need to expand into larger baskets and they've found a competitive partner who can do that for them.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Clearly good for Ocado. For M&S, it's all a bit "how do you do, fellow kids"

BE11:20am

Here's Citi.

chad_john Sure it's cost a lot, but it'll pay back in scale eventually.
red mkt awards higher pe tho BE. thats what counts. logic doesnt come in to it
VV75 the day that Amazon launches their UK grocery business the 750 million quid is down the drain
nightingale20201 WayneJ - ditto FATDAZ comment
chad_john Doesn't justify the bloody divi cut though.
DJ Morning, can we do Interserve please?
Forester Merging ASDA and M&S looks good on a spreadsheet, but in reality is a naff idea.
BE11:21am

The JV will trade as Ocado.com but will use M&S to replace the c.4k own label lines currently provided by Waitrose. The existing Ocado CFC’s will be owned by Ocado but the JV will pay a service fee to Ocado to operate the existing logistics. Future CFC’s will be funded by the JV. The 2018 sales of the JV would have been £1,468m with EBITDA of £34m (although a £15m fee to Waitrose will not have to be paid) suggesting an EV of £1500m for £49m of EBITDA giving c.30x EBITDA. M&S will treat the JV as an associate suggesting Ocado has effective control.

chad_john VV75 - Amazon already have via Fresh, and it's dog sh1t.
red m&s prob has its own customers. thats also one argument
11:21 am
BE11:21am

The deal will be funded by a £600m rights issue which at the current M&S valuation will likely be dilutive to earnings. The rationale for the rights issue appears valid which may limit the discount required. The 40% dividend cut suggests a planned rebasing as if the JV investment is covered by the rights issue the dividend cut is not immediately required in our view. This may suggest further investment in the JV will be needed, more capex in core M&S or to help with reducing the overall debt burden. The signalling of the dividend cut by itself is likely to see the shares down today given its importance to the shareholders.

wayneJ Has anyone actually - and I say this in all seriousness - worked out what part of Ocado is actually unique? 10 sec dd on Youtube show automated grocery warehouses globally - and many suppliers
VV75 @chad, that's not the real attempt I think, just a feeler for the market
BE11:22am

Honestly, though, Ocado have made out like bandits here.

Forester M&S - 4 spuds on a tray for a £1 - that is certainly an unique proposition!
BE11:22am

Ocado maintains ownership of the majority of the current assets, retains its brand name, charges a service fee for its technology under a long term contract, gets a management fee from the JV for operating the logistics, gets access to the M&S customer data and M&S products at cost, gets to choose the CEO and gets up to £750m in cash. M&S gets to recognise 50% of the JV net income post these costs and most importantly 50% of the future earnings stream. There is no agreement on the long term JV outcome but the earn out is after 5 years, suggesting a long term deal is anticipated – M&S need this to make the deal worthwhile, in our view.

wayneJ One of the 'surprises' in the US market is Whole Foods - and the shock that some Americans care about quality. Imagine what it would do for WMT to have M&S food as a store inside the store in Walmarts across the US
red @wayneJthats the point they get a massive pe anyway. board is trying to rerate shares here. shares go up, everyone happy
11:23 am
BE11:23am

Overall – An expensive, but arguably necessary, way to enter the market in the short term but offers long term potential. The rights issue and dividend cut will come as a surprise to many as in our discussions there was limited concern over the strength of the M&S balance sheet given property backing and cash generation.

BE11:24am

Sellside, pretty much as one, talking about it as expensive but necessary for M&S.

wayneJ So basically (unless anyone disagrees) - M&S Board paying £750M as can't be bothers to use Google / YouTube to find alternative suppliers?
BE11:24am

Expensive, sure ................... but why necessary?

chad_john What everyone is getting wrong about M&S is the assumption that their customer base will always be blue rinse - no!
11:25 am
BE11:25am

M&S Food's been flatlining for a while, but that's mostly because it's not a grocer. It's an upscale convenience food chain that reached its expansion ceiling.

chad_john .@BE .. so then it's necessary to expand online, no?
Shinshin Presumably Waitrose isn't just going to shut its service down, and will keep up as a direct competitor. WOnder if they get to walk away with a copy of all the customer data
chad_john (Sorry, I'll calm down soon)
wayneJ M&S trades about 11x - SBRY about the same PE; TSCO a bit higher but that is after some counting difficulties. What exactly is M&S aspiring to? If they want growth it would be helpful if the board actually visited some of their stores....
nightingale20201 don't think MKS had a choice.....their digital strategy and delivery has been poor despite that fact they claim to have 12mm online shoppers...
Soundbuy Story doing the rounds in NH days here of a punter who staked literally all on Ocado, only to watch it bomb........... if he's still holding he's probably giving us all the finger on some yacht in the Caribbean......
BE11:27am

And the solution is to go toe-to-toe with the big-four grocers, who are running their delivery services at levels of profitability so poor they refuse to disclose them?

nightingale20201 Your point on MKS food is valid...the risk for OCDO is that are they trading down the quality of their grocery (Waitrose vs. MKS)
wayneJ Re my comment about expanding M&S into the US - an alternative would be for Walmart to use M&S to spearhead smaller food convenience foods. And remember one of the rationales to buy ASDA in the first place was to get George. On the same basis what could WMT do with M&S clothing.
chad_john I think most people see M&S and Waitrose as on par, quality wise.
BE11:27am

Rather than just spinning off the chain and/or selling it to Whole Foods?

11:27 am
BE11:27am

RBC off the conference call:

FATDAZ @wayneJ I was surprised by MKS strategy when they announced the closure of their London distribution depot and this new news is that squred
FATDAZ squared even
BE11:28am

Waitrose currently provides c4,000 SKUs on Ocado (25% of Ocado sales). 10% of Ocado’s sales come from own label sales (c.£150mn).

BE11:28am

Ocado will now be the exclusive provider of M&S food online. Over the next 18 months, a decision will be made as to which of M&S’ other products online, eg, flowers will be available on the Ocado website. The JV should offer potential to expand M&S’ range online and sell more products on the Ocado site.

wayneJ @Fatdaz - I think my comment about M&S board and stores ought to be extended to the board actually visiting distribution depts
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Ocado has a similar customer profile to M&S – 12mn M&S customers shop online regularly already. Ocado currently over-indexes in the South, while
M&S is strong across the country.

BE11:29am

Potential synergies for Ocado – increased buying power, bigger range [twice as large as Waitrose), sourcing fee saved (approaching £20mn in FY19e].

BE11:29am

Potential synergies for M&S (£70mn/annum) – mainly from buying and scale benefits. The JV doesn’t only increase the product range, but also allows for more efficient line development.
The JV will invest in new CFC buildings, spokes and home delivery vans. There will be incremental capex relating to the shell of the new CFCs.
The JV will be generally asset-light. The larger capex is on Ocado’s side (tech and content). The deferred consideration of £188mn will be based on operating and financial metrics of the JV.
Around £50mn has been allocated from the previously reported Ocado Retail EBITDA to Ocado’s Solutions business, which will be outside the JV. This is to reflect the cost of the technology that Ocado provides, the logistics and the running of the JV.

FATDAZ @Wayne J indeed
wayneJ So will M&S be able to consolidate 50% of the income from the jv - or is it that it will be able to ignore 50% of the losses?
Tom Dalgleish Retailers paying for shelf space!!
11:29 am
BE11:29am

To be clear, there's a decent match between M&S and Ocado food vans UK.

BE11:29am

And there's a fair price to pay to tie them together.

BE11:29am

The problem is that M&S hasn't paid it.

11:29 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 1,032, up 41.5 (+4.19%), High: 1,070, Low: 985.00, Volume: 2.26m
undefined
wayneJ So the basic hypothesis that having failed with in-house organic development of a distribution centre; the same incompetents now want shareholders money to buy 50% of an overvalued competitor.....
BE11:30am

Cripes, didn't mean to waste so much time on that. Okay, what next?

red beggars cant be choosers
11:30 am
Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 1,049, down 251 (-19.31%), High: 1,165, Low: 985.00, Volume: 1.68m
wayneJ The Chief Digital and Data Officer at M&S has a rather unfortunate name......J. Pee
hornblower The Metro £350m raise is going be tough. now trading at 0.8x book so going to be highly dilutive. shareholder list got a few big names but not many institutions.
BE11:31am

So what happened here was that some government quango inexplicably gave most of the first tranche of the RBS "have some money for free" fund to Metro.

wayneJ Given Justin King recently joined the M&S board I think a Sainsbury tie up is actually even more interesting....SBRY + MKS would fit better than SBRY + ASDA
BE11:32am

The shares went up as a result, as you'd expect when a company that doesn't have enough money receives a big wodge of free money.

hornblower 3350m a third of mkt cap
hornblower *£350m
11:32 am
BE11:33am

Which resulted in the shares trading sufficiently wide to NAV to be able to pull the trigger on a £350m cash call.

Forester @hornblower Agree. If you want to buy some shares on a UK bank with an interesting USP, then SvH is the obvious choice. Metro at the bottom of my list!
wayneJ Given what has passed may I ask if Chris Grayling was in anyway involved in the DD re giving money to Metro? Q1: "Are you a good chap?" Q2: "Are you a viable business?" Q3: "Where do we send the money?"
Derf Hiscox pls ?
BE11:34am

Oh, and by the way they're under investigation by the PRA and FCA ....

BE11:35am

So both the Chairman and CEO have their jackets on very shoogly pegs.

PBateman Fresnillo, please
FJ Dilution everywhere. Anything else?
wayneJ May I be really boring - has anyone looked at Ocado accounting? For a food retailer - albeit online - why are its gross margins so much higher than the traditionals - are they recognising delivery and fulfilment below the gross profit line?
Blank canvas if time permits, something on Rio Tinto?
VV75 Do you perhaps have any report on which listed companies are most at risk if the India-Pakistan conflict truly escalates?
11:36 am
BE11:36am

What we end up with is a warning that growth will be much slower, the cash call will need to be substantially under NAV, and as the IRB accreditation won't be through until 2021 at least this is just the first cash call of many.

wayneJ And how will M&S reconcile the Ocado method of accounting with its own? (Is the board even aware of this issue?)
PBateman My local big M&S had a shoplifter who got caught out and started screaming at mums, grannys, kids all kinds of vile abuse. I said where's the security guard (not so great road in greater london), was told there's no budget and that this happens 'a'll the time''.
BE11:37am

Here comes Panmure.

FATDAZ @VV75 that probably depends on the level of escalation and what you believe constitutes a nuclear winter
BE11:38am

Having pre-announced 4Q18 results in January which included RWAs increasing by £0.9bn for certain commercial and specialist BTL loans leading to the CET1 ratio falling by 2.6ppt QoQ to 13.1%, another equity raise was widely expected. Therefore, along with the FY2018 results, Metro Bank last evening announced the intention to raise £350m of additional equity in 1H19 by entering into a standby underwrite agreement with certain banks to fund future growth and maintain a minimum CET1 and leverage ratio of 12% and greater than 4%. FY2023 growth targets have been significantly curtailed, as management now seek to preserve margins and profitability at the expense of strong growth. Despite this, FY2023 RoE target has been reduced to low double digit (from 17-19%), highlighting the increasingly competitive landscape among high street banks. Moreover, with FY2020 targets abandoned, we find it difficult to make an investment case given the lack of short-term visibility and the uncertainty regarding the potential equity required to achieve the new medium-term targets.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Remember when this thing traded at more than 3x NAV? Remember us asking, "why the hell does this thing trade at more than 3x NAV?"?

Grouchmonkey Another vote for Rio, please.
BE11:39am

Metro Bank has received initial notification that the PRA and FCA intend to investigate the circumstances and events that led to the RWA adjustment announced on 23 January 2019. This could potentially lead to significant fines, in our view. Moreover, management now expect that their application with the PRA with regards to the use of Advanced Internal Ratings Based (AIRB) models for residential mortgages is not expected to be completed before 2021, compared to previous expectations of approval by end-2019. We believe this increases the uncertainty as to the bank’s capital requirements over the next couple of years.

BE11:39am

In vestment view – Given the recent performance and abandonment of FY2020 targets including NIM + fees metrics, we believe that the visibility of Metro Bank’s investment case is further reduced. And with the medium-term targets being five years out, we remain uncertain over the level of equity required to achieve these targets. The slower growth and higher than expected equity raise (£350m vs. £200m in our estimates) implies that our returns will be further diluted. Hence, we maintain our Sell rating.

Tom Dalgleish @PB, anecdotally the incidence of shoplifting in Oz has increased too
wayneJ Also anyone worked out how the costs for vouchers are accounted for in the balance sheet on Ocado? - I basically am just trying to understand as the GM and EBITDA margin for its scale is rather 'exciting'
11:40 am
BE11:40am

And KBW, who are meant to be specialists here.

BE11:40am

Following the RWA issue, we left our outlook under review, and after hearing the plan this afternoon it is apparent to us that the shares have more headwinds than tailwinds, which when combined with a premium relative valuation, could make it challenging to outperform over the next 12-24 months. These headwinds include the completion of a £350mm common equity raise, the issuance of £500mm of MREL debt, the prospects for limited near-term ROE improvement, a challenging NIM environment and high expense growth. While the fundamental underbelly of the story (creating "fans") remains intact, we believe the core issue facing the bank, its sub-par ROE, wasn't addressed as much as we would have hoped with the announcement.

PBateman Not been back since and i would imagine most that witnessed that haven't either. Anecdotal obvs but indicative of wider probs. A div cut to boot and i wouldn't be a happyholder.
BE11:41am

As we look forward, the bank's path towards ROE improvement appears long and challenging, which when combined with the upcoming capital need (debt and equity) and a premium valuation relative to its peers of 20+%, leaves us feeling a Market Perform rating is appropriate at this time.

FATDAZ @BE to be frank that sounds like an absolute shambles, will they even be around in 5 years time is my first thought
wayneJ @PBateman - just adds to my view that the board never actually visits the battlefront.
GBKrona @Blankcanvas, Grouchmonkey - did you read this on Rio by Neil Hume? Long time since he was on ML!!https://www.ft.com/content/f5c61876-3a58-11e9-b72b-2c7f526ca5d0
Grouchmonkey Re Metro - management at Lloyds must be dreading the call from the Secretary of State suggesting they buy the thing......
hornblower @wayne J - Ocado accounting has done well to present a picture of a product supermarkets should buy. The adage if Goldman are selling don't buy comes to mind
wayneJ @Fatdaz - Metro - the Chairman's personality is 'large' and all encompassing....
Soundbuy I blame the dog bowls ......
PBateman i made a formal complaint as it was just the worst thing i've witnessed in a long time, said that action would be taken. i must call back in and take a look
FATDAZ @grouch monkey once bitten ..... surely
PBateman Metro rallied hard from the bottom a few weeks ago
red @hornbloweryes, quite. never pays to be a have goldman as a counterparty
PBateman now back where it was.. billion quid for a bank hmm
Blank canvas GBKrona: yes, thanks, I saw it earlier
11:42 am
BE11:43am

Gonna suggest that odd £120m bung from the Banking Competition Remedies quango might get a bit of attention in the future.

undefined
Soundbuy Probably misguided to believe dog bowls could provide some kinda moat...........
wayneJ @Red - / @Horn - so rv £1.599bn; EBITDA of 59M; but then u note that 'other income' is 71.9 - so if it was not for this item we would have a loss?
red @wayneJthey see what they want to see
BE11:44am

Turning to requests ..... Rio and Hiscox mentioned.

wayneJ And marketing costs 'exclude voucher costs'
Grouchmonkey @GBKrona thanks. Was more interested in analyst reaction to the forward statements re Oyu Tolgoi and prospects for Pilbara copper discovery.
FATDAZ @wayneJ was never comfortable with idea of 'challenger banks' unless they had an independent clearing capability without which they were at the mercy of bigger peers hadn't anticipated an inability to execute though I suppose Metro buying in Mortgages from hedge funds was a sign that it wasn't working on the high street
PBateman Ocado at tottenham court road station most weeks dishing out vouchers
11:44 am
BE11:45am

(What's happened to Hiscox? Have I missed something.)

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 4,399, up 13 (+0.30%), High: 4,480, Low: 4,386, Volume: 1.33m
FATDAZ @soundbuy ouch
Tom Dalgleish @Grouch, the local media has gone quiet on Rio/Pattersons/Pilbara Cu
Soundbuy Goldman been busy on the insurers this am., didn't see Hiscox
BE11:46am

Soaring 0.3% on a $4bn special dividend.

wayneJ @BE - hope this link is acceptable: @Fatdaz - I always found the following to be 'interesting' - https://www.occ.gov/news-issuances/news-releases/2008/nr-occ-2008-135.html (@BE please zap if inappropriate)
red @FATDAZcan work if you take second line customers and take high rates but the proof in then in the picking. hard act to balance. maybe was easier for them to buy in ready made but u are never sure of quality. just cos it says on the tin doesnt make it so
Tom Dalgleish A geologist said it's not so unusual to build an airstrip for a geo camp where the alternative is a bone jarring 4 hours on a dirt track
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Rio's paying out 14% of its market cap over 12 months. That's pretty remarkable, not least because we keep on writing about how various comms markets are still at or close to deficit.

FATDAZ Speaking of Goldman's might they or rather their marcus banking upstart consider buying Metro for a bit of high street exposure and scale they could presumably re jig balance sheet etc and provide longer-term stability no?
wayneJ And -https://digitalcommons.law.villanova.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2001&context=thirdcircuit_2014
BE11:48am

Countering that are project delays, as well as guidance that cash will have to be spent on something other than shareholders soon.

BE11:49am

Morgan Stanley can summarise from here.

red @FATDAZpotential customers at diff ends of scale
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Solid earnings with modest net income beat vs MSe and consensus with c.USD1.5bn lower net debt too. Cash returns modestly better and guidance largely unchanged or in line. However, we expect the additional delays to its key copper growth project, Oyu Tolgoi, to drive shares today. Stay Equalweight

Earnings solid with USD0.3bn (4%) beat at net income mainly on lower interest costs with in-line EBITDA. This translated into USD1.5bn lower net debt. The ordinary dividend is marginally better at USD3.07 (MSe USD2.97/consensus USD3.04). The size of the special return of USD4.0bn is in line with consensus (MSe USD3.5bn). The method of returning it is a special dividend rather than buy back which may surprise consensus but in our view makes no difference to value creation since the shares trade close to our estimate of fair value. Guidance is largely in-line with previous targets or close to MSe and consensus. The main issue that will drive the shares today is the additional delay and likely material capex lift at Oyu Tolgoi. This is the only key growth project in one of Rio Tinto's preferred commodities and a further delay is disappointing.

wayneJ But a bit like M&S board being unable to use Google; it appears many MTRO investors have suffered from the same quirk...
Soundbuy Re comms - Palladium been on a screamer.........
BE11:50am

We see limited/modest EPS changes post 2018 results. and the shares are relatively fairly valued in our view at 6.9x/4.7x EV/EBITDA and 6.9%/11.9% FCF yield (not adjusted for Oyu Tolgoi capex) on base case and spot price scenario respectively. Financial risks remains very low with no net debt at year end if spot prices prevail. On the other hand, the group has limited re-investment opportunities for now and its single biggest project, Oyu Tolgoi is further delayed beyond end of 3Q2021. Growth for growth sake is clearly not the objective but a balance between capital returns and a modest rate of reinvestment for growth in a mix of smaller incremental projects and greenfield is our preference.

PBateman haha, customers with lots of used £20s in deposit boxes vs a few hundred k to sit and earn 1.5%
BE11:50am

And Goldman, saying the same.

Soundbuy 6 month chart a joy..........
11:50 am
BE11:51am

Overall - a net neutral set of results. Financials were inline - EBITDA was US$18.2bn [inline with consensus - Vuma]. FY18 dividend came in at USc307/shr vs. consensus at USc302/shr. The Grasberg cash is being returned to shareholders via a US$4bn special dividend (USc243/shr - c. 4% dividend yield), which was not a surprise given most investors expected the cash to be returned. While balance sheet turned net cash - it is because of some delays in tax payments (US$1.3bn). Adding the impact of the special dividend and remaining buy-back the pro-forma net debt works out to be US$8bn.

BE11:51am

On growth projects - the company said that Oyo Tolgoi could face cost schedule overruns - a slight -ve today. On guidance - the company made no changes to production capex.

red @PBatemanits actually 1.3% ish plus the bonus at the end of the 12 month period
PBateman right you are
wayneJ Any grey on how the 'accounting issues' impact the long term normalised ROE at MTRO?
red but its still hard to beat. thats the sad truth for savers
BE11:52am

Standalone - this is a strong set of results with the company returning greater than 10% in terms of shareholder returns in FY19 {dividend + special dividend + buy-back}.

FATDAZ @red you can open a Marcus account with £1 apparently so not buying that and anecdotally the people I know with Metro bank accounts are well off , anyway just flying kites :)
11:52 am
BE11:52am

But we think the debate amongst investors is likely to be twofold:

BE11:52am

a} IO is artificially higher due to Vale accident; and

BE11:52am

b} On returns the greater than 10% return is due to asset sales which could mean that the returns have peaked in FY19.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

As such, investors could question if returns could improve from here?

BE11:53am

We expect limited impact on the stock post today’s release.

i ITV pls

Broken up like that because the spam filter didn't like it, for some reason.

11:53 am

One of the quieter enclaves of the City, which I guess means the TP has peace to contemplate its policy of hardly ever forcing companies into put out statements on media reports.

Mylan results yesterday

During which they made pretty confident noises about generic Advair Diskus

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

The company launched the product on 12 February at a 70% discount to the branded version, a more aggressive pricing strategy than we had anticipated. Wixela™ Inhub™ is a dry powder formulation delivered using the DEV610 inhaler, a device developed and manufactured by Bespak. The successful roll-out of the product is likely to impact Bespak’s underlying growth from FY2020. We have assumed that Bespak’s agreement with Mylan is based on a fixed unit price per inhaler, so the end user price should not affect Bespak’s revenue. With such an aggressive pricing policy, Mylan is clearly aiming to maximize market share gains as rapidly as possible, despite having the first-to-market advantage with a generic Advair® in the US. Bespak has already manufactured launch quantities of the inhaler and our forecasts assume no further orders until FY2020. Our forecasts remain unchanged, but news of Mylan’s pricing strategy and positive outlook raises our confidence in forecasts for Consort Medical in FY2020 and beyond. We retain our BUY recommendation and fair value of 1230p per share.

Here's Jefferies to ask exactly that.

BE12:12pm

In a surprise announcement, prior to the scheduled FY18 results, Beiersdorf (BEI) have joined Henkel (HEN3), Colgate and Coke in 'the reset club,' in a dramatic first act by new CEO Stefan De Loecker and CFO Desi Temperley. BEI is to commit €70m to €80m of new investment (100-110bps margin equivalent) in FY19 as the start of a multi-year programme, 'CARE+,' to accelerate growth. CARE+ is intended to accelerate BEI's presence in 'white spaces,' strengthen its skincare offer, step up digitisation, improve productivity and increase environmental commitments.

BE12:13pm

FY18 Group OSG of 5.4% had already been disclosed on Jan 17. OSG in Consumer was 5.0% & tesa of 6.8%. Implied Q4 sales at Group level of 3.6% compared to 6.0% at the 9M. Consumer slowed from 5.6% at 9M to 3.2% in Q4. The new news in last night's statement is the brand-level picture: Nivea accelerated slightly in Q4 to 3.1% OSG but all other segments slowed significantly: Derma from 6.3% in the 9M to 4.7% in Q4; La Prairie from 47% to 14% and healthcare (sticking plasters) from negative 1.3% to negative 3.3%. tesa (Adhesive tapes, 19% of sales) OSG slowed from 7.8% in the 9M to 3.8% at Q4.

12:13 pm
BE12:13pm

The implication from BEI, HEN3's & Colgate's resets is that around €500m of incremental 'growth' investment is destined for the mass HPC category. This is bound to up the ante for Unilever (ULVR), who compete with all three of the resetters in big categories like skincare, haircare, dentifrice and laundry. We therefore expect the credibility of ULVR's 2020 margin target to be the subject of even greater debate. And if BEI think the game is up at 15% margins, and with all the economies of scale that flow from a mono-brand strategy with Nivea, what price RB, with 27% margins?

BE12:13pm

Ditto Citi.

BE12:14pm

This margin reset comes after many similar events in the industry
over the past few months, and marks a necessary pivot towards a more traditional growth agenda after years of what had been seen as too extreme a cost cutting. That said, this may thus put pressure via negative read across on the very few names having stuck to their margin targets or high profitability levels.

But back to the headlines. Here's Barclays.

BE12:19pm

2018 results were slightly better than expectations (2% at EPS) but 2019 has started poorly in terms of advertising (Q1 down 7%, the first four months down 3-4%).

ITV is also unveiling, as expected, their foray into SVOD (Subscription Video on Demand) with a contemplated joint venture with the BBC called Britbox. ITV believes that other broadcasters will join. This comes with extra investment of £25m in 2019E, £40m in 2020E and declining thereafter. The fact that this is a joint effort is positive, the investments less so.

We would also highlight the fact that ITV’s audience was up 3% to 17.1bn viewed hours across all devices in 2018. Free-to-air television appears to decline less than the majority of the market believes it seems.

Overall, when there are medium term questions, investors usually follow short-term trends and they are not positive for ITV. Re-iterate Equal Weight.

BE12:20pm

Audience

With most of the market believing that free-to-air is a dying business model, we would point out that ITV actual viewing across all devices is actually up 3% to 17.1bn hours. We do not have a lot of history for this metrics (ITV only started disclosing it last year) but the market bearish view is based mostly on declining consumption especially among young adults. This is not happening yet.

BE12:20pm

FY 2018 results were slightly ahead of our forecasts, with revenue up 3% at
3,211m (MSe 3,203m); EBITA down 3% at 785m (MSe 787m) and adj EPS down 4%
at 15.4p (14.9p). Broadcasting and Online revenues performed better than our
expectations, with revenues up 1% to 2,096m (MSe 2,070m) and EBITA down 7%
at 555m (MSe 527m).
The company has announced new investment in a joint SVOD service with the
BBC (BritBox). ITV plans “net investment” at the ITV plc level of up to 25m in
2019, and 40m in 2020. This investment will decline from 2020 onwards, but the
company has not indicated a break-even year for the investment. We had
assumed 35m pa for the new venture, although this is not yet incorporated into
our forecasts.
The outlook on advertising is slightly below our forecasts, with total advertising
for the first 4 months of the year expected to be down 3-4%, vs our expectation
of -2.5%. For the full year, ITV expects “good” organic revenue growth at ITV
Studios; double digit online revenue growth; and flags tough comparatives for
first half revenues and profits from the Football World Cup. Viewing share so far
in 2019 is solid, with ITV Family share of viewing up 6% and volume of viewing up
2%.
We are expecting ITV’s TV advertising to decline -2% in 2019, model 689m of
EBITA. Consensus currently expects TV advertising growth of around zero, with
EBITA at around 730m. With the softer start to the year, tough comps from the
World Cup and the additional BritBox investment, we see consensus forecasts
coming down 3-4% pre BritBox, and perhaps 7-8% post the BritBox investment.
